Well, even though it has not happened to me, I can certainly tell you about it since one of my closest friends had it. She was diagnosed with GD and went on a diet. She only ate salads and meat, chicken or fish (moderately). No juice or fruits (just berries), only a special milk and yogurt people with diabetes, and lots of water. They told her that the baby was bigger than normal and that she had to do this. Well, she went on this diet, but failed to get rid of her diabetes. We have heard awful stories about babies and GD; but she went on to giving birth to a healthy, beautiful baby girl. I remember, just days before her due date she went in for an u/s. The doctor told her that the baby’s weight was 11 lbs if I remember correctly – too big and blah blah blah. When her baby was born she weighed 7 lbs and 4 oz. Are u/s even accurate? No.  Her baby does not have low blood sugar or anything related to that GD her mom was diagnosed with.I would eat healthy and avoid sugar as much as possible to be on the safe side. I believe working out in moderation helps. Sorry to hear you were diagnosed with GD. But don’t stress too much. I am certain your baby will come to this world strong and healthy and will keep my fingers crossed.

I wouldn't worry about it.  Not at this point.  I have failed my 1 hr test with every one of my last 3 pregnancies and I'm pretty sure I probably will again this time.  But my 3 hr usually comes back ok.  The last time it came back borderline, I was just told to watch my diet.  I had no problems and baby was born 7 lbs 15 oz on his due date. The 1 hr doesn't tell you that you HAVE GD it tells you if you have a higher risk.  If it comes back high, they'll want to do a 3 hr test.  If you arent' familiar with that one I can tell you more about it.
